resources.string: * image in scaled-down versions is cut into tiles
* right tiles are fetched as needed
* image aspect ratio is unknown in layout creation
* ViewMode defines how image will be mapped into the view
* configurable background color, border width and color
* configurable size, cache shared among all views
You can see red guide-lines along each tile and its diagonals (and some other visualisations). These are by default disabled and can be enabled per view through layout params or constructor.

Zoom with pinch in/out and double tap. Flick and scroll with one or two fingers to move the image (with intertia). Gestures can be combined without any twitching. Apart from that, single tap can be processed through callback that returns tap\'s coordinates within view and also bounding box (part of view that contains actual image).

TiledImageView should be defined with fixed size or match_parent. These extreme width/height ratio examples here demonstrate how image is zoomed and aligned to fulfil given View-mode strategy. View-mode can be defined in layout/constructor and changed dynamically through setter.

Parts of this black-and-white newspaper are highlighted with semitransparent color, rectangular border or both. Typical usage is enclosing search results. Nontransparent color can be used to cover content.
Here you can switch between different images to see how fluent all the juggling of tiles between network, memory and disk cache is. This app clears cache on startup.
